regMasCalc.title: Answer these questions and find out, at no cost, whether you are eligible for the Mass Regularization and how to prepare for it
regMasCalc.update: According to the draft law, updated on

q1.title: Did you enter Spain before December 31, 2025?
q1.help: We ask this because the law states that you must have entered Spain without interruption before December 31, 2025.

q2.title: For better accuracy, could you tell us the date you entered Spain?
q2.help: There are other alternatives if you cannot apply for the Mass Regularization. To help you more accurately, we need this information.

q3.title: Could you prove that you have lived in Spain for 5 continuous months?
q3.help: The draft law states that the applicant must have lived in Spain for 5 continuous months before applying and must have entered the country before 12/31/25. You can prove this through registration (padrÃ³n), rental contracts, utility bills, etc. If you do not have registration, there are other ways to prove it.

q4.title: Right now, what is your status in Spain?
q4.help: There are other alternatives if you cannot apply for the Mass Regularization. To help you more accurately, we need this information.

options.asilo: Asylum seeker or International Protection applicant
options.arraigo: With a residency application (arraigo) in progress

q5.title: Do you have family with you here?
q5.help: We mean minor children, children with a disability, or a spouse/partner. We ask because you may obtain a broader or longer residence authorization if you do.

q6.title: What is your nationality or country of origin?
q6.help: We ask so we can offer a more detailed assessment or, if applicable, other options based on your nationality.

q7.title: Which province or region do you currently live in?
q7.help: Please note that processing times may depend on this.

eligible.intro: Based on your answers and the requirements proposed in the draft law, you may be eligible to apply for the Mass Regularization.
eligible.recommendationsTitle: If you want to be ready and get ahead, we recommend:

recommendations.r1: Keep proof of your entry into Spain handy (tickets, reservations, passport stamp, etc.).
recommendations.r2: Gather documents that prove your stay in Spain: registration (padrÃ³n), medical appointments, bank transfers, etc.
recommendations.r3: Check that your passport is valid; if not, renew it at your countryâ€™s consulate.
recommendations.r4: Request a Criminal Record Certificate and, if needed, start the clearing/cancellation process. Also check any police records.
recommendations.r5: If possible, request the Social Roots (Arraigo Social) report (if you meet the two-year stay requirement), or gather information from your country of origin about assets or income. Note that this documentation may need an apostille.
recommendations.r6: If you are in an irregular situation, gather evidence of your status (expired permit, asylum denial, etc.), as this documentation may be relevant to support a vulnerability pathway.
recommendations.r7: Leave your details and we will notify you when there are official updates and concrete steps to apply for the Mass Regularization.

notEligible.body: However, that does not mean you have no options. There are other regularization pathways and permits that may fit your situation, such as arraigo routes or a study stay permit.
